articles.headline: Police in Cleveland Accept Tough Standards on Force
articles.snippet: The Cleveland police department has agreed to follow some of the most exacting standards in the nation over how and when its officers can use force, part of a settlement with the Justice Department.
articles.abstract: The Cleveland police department has agreed to follow some of the most exacting standards in the nation over how and when its officers can use force, part of a settlement with the Justice Department.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Cleveland police department, which has become synonymous with the racially charged debate over police tactics, has agreed to follow some of the most exacting standards in the nation over how and when its officers can use force, and it will accept close oversight to make sure those rules are not ignored, city and federal officials said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: The ‘King of Cable’ Behind a Charter-Time Warner Cable Deal
articles.snippet: John Malone made his fortune as a pioneering baron of American cable, and has had his hands in everything from the Discovery Channel to DirecTV.
articles.abstract: John Malone made his fortune as a pioneering baron of American cable, and has had his hands in everything from the Discovery Channel to DirecTV.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the billionaire media executive John C. Malone bought a million acres of Maine forestland in 2011, assuming the mantle of America’s top landowner from his friend and fellow mogul Ted Turner, he made no triumphant announcement. Instead, he shielded his identity through a shell company.

articles.headline: A Drive for Swing State Votes Has Colorado’s Latinos Listening
articles.snippet: Both parties are planning an aggressive courtship of Latino voters for 2016, with Republicans trying to chip away at the Democrats’ hold on the bloc.
articles.abstract: Both parties are planning an aggressive courtship of Latino voters for 2016, with Republicans trying to chip away at the Democrats’ hold on the bloc.
articles.lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — Under the red roof of Lupita’s Mexican Restaurant, Elizabeth Oxley and her 23-year-old daughter, Leticia, work seven days a week, from breakfast to last call, to keep pace with the price of their family’s American dream. There is a $250,000 renovation on their restaurant to pay off. Mortgage bills. College loans.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Settle Meaning of ‘One Person One Vote’
articles.snippet: The court has so far not resolved the issue of whether the principle means that voting districts should have the same number of people, or the same number of eligible voters.
articles.abstract: The court has so far not resolved the issue of whether the principle means that voting districts should have the same number of people, or the same number of eligible voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Tuesday to hear a case that will answer a long-contested question about a bedrock principle of the American political system: the meaning of “one person one vote.”

articles.headline: Government R&D, Private Profits and the American Taxpayer
articles.snippet: Taxpayer-financed research can generate large rewards down the road. In an era of tight budgets, a slice of the profits could finance new innovations.
articles.abstract: Taxpayer-financed research can generate large rewards down the road. In an era of tight budgets, a slice of the profits could finance new innovations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Academy of Radiology Research has resorted to a creative tactic in a bid to halt the decline in public funding for science: It showed Congress a picture of how much the nation earns from the government’s research dollar.

articles.headline: Vox Media Adds ReCode to Its Stable of Websites
articles.snippet: The deal would give ReCode, a technology news site, access to a wider audience, something it has struggled to build in a crowded field.
articles.abstract: The deal would give ReCode, a technology news site, access to a wider audience, something it has struggled to build in a crowded field.
articles.lead_paragraph: ReCode, the news website led by the veteran journalists Walt Mossberg and Kara Swisher, is being acquired by Vox Media, a deal that reflects the turmoil among digital organizations focused on covering the tech industry.

articles.headline: Cyberattack Exposes I.R.S. Tax Returns
articles.snippet: Criminals gained access to past tax returns of more than 100,000 people and used personal information to claim $50 million in fraudulent refunds, the agency said.
articles.abstract: Criminals gained access to past tax returns of more than 100,000 people and used personal information to claim $50 million in fraudulent refunds, the agency said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Criminals used stolen data to gain access to past tax returns of more than 100,000 people through an application on the Internal Revenue Service’s website, the agency said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Trial Opens in Collapse of Dewey & LeBoeuf Firm
articles.snippet: Accused of accounting tricks to defraud lenders, three former executives instead blamed “greedy” lawyers who took clients, hastening the firm’s demise.
articles.abstract: Accused of accounting tricks to defraud lenders, three former executives instead blamed “greedy” lawyers who took clients, hastening the firm’s demise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three former executives of the law firm of Dewey & LeBoeuf, who are accused of using accounting gimmicks to defraud its lenders, sought to deflect the blame for the once-prominent firm’s collapse during the start of their trial on Tuesday.

articles.headline: A Murky Road Ahead for Android, Despite Market Dominance
articles.snippet: Android is the most popular operating system in the world by far, but it is under siege by low-end upstarts and fares poorly versus Apple’s iOS in ad revenue.
articles.abstract: Android is the most popular operating system in the world by far, but it is under siege by low-end upstarts and fares poorly versus Apple’s iOS in ad revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2005, Google bought a tiny mobile software company named Android, and almost nobody in the technology industry saw its potential — not even Eric Schmidt, Google’s chairman and then chief executive. “One day Larry and Sergey bought Android, and I didn’t even notice,” Mr. Schmidt told reporters in 2009, referring to Larry Page and Sergey Brin, Google’s founders.

articles.headline: Charter Customers Say Bigger Isn’t Likely to Mean Better
articles.snippet: Despite recent improvements in consumer satisfaction ratings, many of the cable company’s subscribers believe a merger won’t improve service.
articles.abstract: Despite recent improvements in consumer satisfaction ratings, many of the cable company’s subscribers believe a merger won’t improve service.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Maybe it will go from an F-minus to an F.”
